key_insight: Spiking neural networks can be configured to solve finite element method (FEM) linear systems directly, using event-driven neural dynamics to produce accurate FEM solutions with much lower energy cost than conventional solvers.
problem_solved: Traditional FEM solvers are computationally and energy intensive, limiting real‑time, edge, and large‑scale physics simulations and making it hard to exploit neuromorphic hardware for scientific computing.
method: Map FEM assembly (mesh → sparse stiffness/mass matrices) onto recurrent spiking network connectivity so synaptic weights encode linear-system coefficients.

Use event-driven spiking dynamics (e.g., integrate-and-fire) as an iterative solver where spike timing and rates converge to the FEM solution; read out nodal values from membrane potentials or spike statistics.
Demonstrate accuracy, convergence and energy/time benefits via simulations and/or neuromorphic hardware comparisons against classical CPU/GPU solvers.
impact: Provides a path to energy‑efficient, low‑latency PDE solvers suitable for edge and neuromorphic platforms and tight integration of physics solvers with AI workflows (e.g., physics‑informed learning, real‑time simulation).
visual_elements: Schematic pipeline: PDE → mesh → matrix → spiking network (icons for each stage) to show the mapping
Side‑by‑side bar chart comparing energy use and latency: spiking/neuromorphic vs CPU/GPU solvers
Convergence plot: error vs time (or iterations) showing spiking dynamics reaching the FEM solution
Annotated diagram of a mesh node and corresponding neuron with incoming synapses representing matrix entries
paper_title: Solving finite element methods with spiking networks
paper_authors: Wenhao Song, Zixu Wang, J. Joshua Yang
